title: Boy left horribly scarred by explosion burns after firework blows up on his chest
text:

A mum wants a ban on the public sale of fireworks after her son was hit by an exploding rocket.

Ben McCabe was four when he suffered agonising burns from a firework exploding on his chest.

He was at a display near his home in North Lanarkshire, Scotland when a stray rocket flew inside his jacket setting his shirt on fire.

Ben, now 12, suffered third degree burns to his chest, neck, right arm and behind his left ear, reports the Daily Record .

He has endured multiple skin grafts and continues to receive treatment to repair the devastating damage.

(Image: McCabe Family/SWNS.com)

(Image: Daily Record)

Yesterday, mum Amy pledged her absolute support to Scottish Government moves to ban the sale of fireworks to the public.

There are widespread fears of the devices being set off in back gardens and on streets.

Many neighbourhoods are being described as akin to “war zones”, with fireworks used as weapons against the emergency services.

Internet ads reveal a frightening range of pyrotechnics.

Amy said: “Obviously I am very strongly in the direction of a complete ban on the sale of fireworks to the general public.”

(Image: McCabe Family/ SWNS.com)

(Image: Daily Record)

But she doesn’t want to see organised displays outlawed.

Amy added: “Too many people enjoy it and I can’t stop people enjoying what they like. But I don’t think it’s right that the general public should get access to fireworks.

“I appreciate that might be hard to enforce and that we may need a change in legislation.

“Perhaps a system where people must complete a course before being allowed to buy fireworks – along the lines of a food hygiene course or something similar.”

A Scottish Government consultation revealed an overwhelming majority support a ban on the public sale of fireworks.

(Image: Daily Record)

(Image: Daily Record)

More than 16,000 people responded amid mounting concerns about lethal explosives being used irresponsibly and recklessly.

Almost nine in 10 would support an outright ban on the sale of fireworks.

More than nine in 10 want to tighten controls on sales, and the same number feel there should be stricter controls on fireworks use.

A YouGov sample poll commissioned by the Scottish Government found 71 per cent of adults want tighter controls on firework sales to the public – with more than half backing a total ban.

Ben’s recovery has been made easier thanks to the Scottish Burned Children’s Club run by a former firefighter Mark Stevenson, which helps kids come to terms with trauma they have suffered.

(Image: Daily Record)

(Image: Daily Record)

Down the years, Ben has bonded with other young burns victims enjoying outdoor activities such as boating and hiking. Amy is convinced it restored her son’s confidence after the accident.

Mark said: “Having campaigned for five years with Ben as our poster-boy, we’re over the moon the public sees some great sense in this.”

Scotland’s community safety minister Ash Denham said: “Over the last few years we’ve seen a lot of anti-social behaviour around bonfire night.

“We’ve seen instances where police officers have been injured and members of the public have felt quite unsafe because people have been using fireworks in the street, launching them at people.

“I’d like to work with the UK Government on restrictions to the sale of fireworks.”
description: Ben McCabe suffered third degree burns all over his body after a stray rocket flew inside his jacket when he was four - now mum is calling for fireworks ban
